questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss during this time. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting pedal edema. An endoscopy shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus. Biopsy shows parietal cell atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serotonin-secreting gastric tumors, also known as gastric carcinoid tumors, are often asymptomatic but may manifest with symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, most commonly if the tumor spreads to the liver. A classic symptom of carcinoid syndrome is diarrhea, as seen in this patient, however, episodic flushing and bronchospasm would also be expected, which are absent here. Furthermore, endoscopy in a patient with a serotonin-secreting gastric tumor would reveal a submucosal mass as opposed to prominent gastric rugae, and a biopsy would show prominent rosettes rather than parietal cell atrophy, as seen here.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's findings are consistent with Ménétrier disease (protein-losing hyperplastic gastropathy), which is a result of the proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells. The pathogenesis involves increased signaling of EGFR, which results in the proliferation of epithelial cells of the mucous cell compartment.
Image Description:

CT scan of the abdomen (coronal section, oral and IV contrast)

There is significant hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa that is visible as thick, convoluted rugae projecting into the gastric lumen (green overlay).
A large simple hepatic cyst is also visible in the right lobe of the liver (red overlay).

The appearance of the stomach is typical of hypertrophic gastropathy (Ménétrier disease).

C) INCORRECT:

Neoplasia of the submucosal lymphoid tissue, or gastric lymphoma, can present with abdominal pain and weight loss, although edema would not be expected. Endoscopic findings may also include thickened rugae. However, histopathologic examination would show abnormal lymphoid tissue rather than parietal cell atrophy, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic H. pylori infection may cause symptoms of dyspepsia, including abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, as seen in this patient. However, it would not cause edema. On endoscopy, the fundus is typically spared, with predominantly antral lesions showing gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. In addition, histopathologic examination would show H. pylori and chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa with atrophy, gland loss, and metaplastic changes rather than parietal cell atrophy, as seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive somatostatin secretion may be caused by a somatostatinoma. Patients present with abdominal pain and weight loss, in addition to the triad of glucose intolerance, gallstones, and diarrhea/steatorrhea. Edema is not a common feature. If localized to the stomach, the tumor can be seen as a submucosal mass on endoscopy, which is not seen here. In addition, histopathologic examination would show densely granular cells in a rosette pattern, which is a common finding in neuroendocrine tumors.

F) INCORRECT:

Ectopic secretion of gastrin causes Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). Patients with ZES commonly present with dyspeptic symptoms and weight loss, as seen in this patient. However, peptic ulcers, steatorrhea, and upper gastrointestinal bleeding would also be expected. Furthermore, although over 90% of patients with ZES have prominent gastric rugae on endoscopy, a biopsy would show parietal cell hyperplasia rather than atrophy, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dyspeptic symptoms (i.e., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea), weight loss, and possible hypoproteinemia (as evidenced by bilateral pedal edema). In combination with prominent gastric rugae on endoscopy and atrophic parietal cells on histology, these features are diagnostic of Ménétrier disease.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has seen some blood in her vomit. She woke up with nausea and subsequently vomited once. The vomitus was yellow and blood-streaked. She reports drinking heavily at a birthday party the day before. When she came home at night, she took some ibuprofen “to prevent a hangover the next day.” The patient has not had any episodes of epigastric pain, postprandial heaviness, or early satiety before today. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome, for which she takes warfarin. Other medications include occasional ibuprofen for headaches and an oral contraceptive. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 1–2 beers on the weekends with episodes of binge drinking about once a month. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nondistended with mild epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?

choices.text: Tearing of the esophageal mucous membrane
Superficial disruption of the gastric mucosa
Rupture of dilated submucosal esophageal veins
Damage to the deeper layers of the duodenal mucosa

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tearing of the esophageal mucous membrane is known as a Mallory-Weiss tear and occurs due to an increase in intraesophageal pressure, such as that caused by forceful vomiting related to heavy alcohol use. However, these lesions typically occur after multiple episodes of severe vomiting rather than during the initial episode. Moreover, this patient's NSAID use and smoking put her at greater risk of a different cause of bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

In Boerhaave syndrome, increased intrathoracic pressure, such as that caused by forceful vomiting after binge drinking, results in transmural perforation of the esophagus. However, this typically occurs after multiple episodes of severe vomiting rather than during the initial episode. Moreover, in a patient with Boerhaave syndrome, clinical findings would also include severe pain, signs of respiratory distress, mediastinal or subcutaneous emphysema, or signs of sepsis, none of which are present here.

C) CORRECT:

Acute erosive gastropathy is characterized by superficial disruption of the gastric mucosa in response to acute exposure to drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, aspirin) and/or exogenous substances such as alcohol, tobacco, or cocaine. Other substances that cause injury to gastric mucosa include caffeine, corrosive substances, and certain supplements (e.g., iron, potassium). Ischemic injury, e.g., in sepsis or hypovolemia, may also result in damage to the gastric mucosa. Clinical features include symptoms of gastritis (e.g., epigastric pain), nausea/vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., hematemesis). The risk of bleeding due to acute erosive gastropathy is increased in patients with risk factors such as anticoagulant use, a history of coagulopathy, or a history of chronic disease. Treatment consists of discontinuing the offending agents and antacid therapy with a proton pump inhibitor.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the stomach

A circular, hematin-covered erosion surrounded by a halo of fibrinous exudate is visible on the erythematous mucosa of the pyloric antrum. Several smaller erosions are also visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of dilated esophageal or gastric submucosal veins is the cause of variceal bleeding. This manifests with hematemesis in patients with portal hypertension, which is most commonly due to cirrhosis. While this patient's alcohol use may put her at risk of developing cirrhosis, she has no features of chronic liver disease (e.g., jaundice, palmar erythema, hepatomegaly) on physical examination. Moreover, acute variceal bleeding is a potentially life-threatening condition, frequently resulting in hemodynamic instability and hemorrhagic shock.

E) INCORRECT:

Duodenal ulcers form as a result of damage to the duodenal mucosa, which penetrates the muscularis mucosa, and can manifest with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Smoking, drinking, and use of NSAIDs are risk factors for peptic ulcer disease (PUD). However, this patient has no history suggestive of PUD (e.g., dyspepsia, pain relieved with food intake). Although PUD cannot be entirely excluded without endoscopy, this patient's clinical presentation is most likely caused by a different condition.
questions.hint: A single episode of vomiting leading to hematemesis in a younger patient is most likely due to an acute process rather than a chronic condition.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman is hospitalized for volume depletion in the setting of a 6-month history of progressive, chronic diarrhea. Her diarrhea did not improve with various dietary modifications, including a lactose-free diet. Celiac serologies, thyrotropin level, stool culture, stool ova and parasite testing, stool Clostridioides difficile toxin testing, and colonoscopy with biopsy were all unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Albumin (g/dL)
2.5
3.5–5.5



Total protein (g/dL)
5.1
5.5–8.0



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
11,700
4500–11,000



Eosinophil count (%)
13
0–8



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.0
12.0–16.0


The patient’s renal function, liver function tests, and platelet count are normal. An upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy reveals an eosinophilic infiltrate in the small intestinal mucosa. A duodenal aspirate and antibodies for strongyloidiasis are negative.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mesalamine and sulfasalazine are used to treat inflammatory bowel disease, not EG.

B) INCORRECT:

Rifaximin is used to treat small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, which can also cause diarrhea, but it is not appropriate for managing EG.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesalamine and sulfasalazine are used to treat inflammatory bowel disease, not EG.

D) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is often used in cases of poor motility due to disorders such as scleroderma.

E) CORRECT:

An eosinophilic infiltrate in the small intestinal mucosa in a patient with chronic diarrhea is indicative of an eosinophilic enteropathy. Eosinophilic gastroenteritis (EG) is an inflammatory disorder of unclear etiology, typically characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the stomach and small intestine. In a patient with newly diagnosed EG presenting with severe protein-losing enteropathy and volume depletion, the most appropriate therapy is a systemic glucocorticoid, such as methylprednisolone. This often produces an immediate clinical response, and it can be tapered once a patient is clinically stabilized. Treatment for milder forms of EG can include an elimination diet, mast-cell stabilizers, and leukotriene-receptor antagonists.

Because strongyloidiasis can have a clinical presentation similar to that of EG, and because glucocorticoid treatment in a patient with strongyloidiasis can induce a hyperinfection that can be fatal, the diagnosis of strongyloides infection must be excluded before glucocorticoid therapy is initiated; hemagglutination antibodies for strongyloides are most sensitive and specific.

Key learning point: The most appropriate therapy for a patient with newly diagnosed eosinophilic gastroenteritis who has severe protein-losing enteropathy and volume depletion is a systemic glucocorticoid, such as methylprednisolone.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of burning epigastric pain that begins soon after meals. He has been taking over-the-counter pain relievers daily for several months due to chronic knee discomfort. He experiences frequent nausea and sometimes vomits to ease his symptoms. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the epigastric region without rebound or guarding.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Functional dyspepsia involves chronic upper abdominal discomfort without structural pathology. Although symptoms like burning epigastric pain and nausea may suggest a functional disorder, the patient's NSAID use and postprandial pain indicate mucosal injury. Functional dyspepsia typically presents with more variable, less meal-related discomfort.

B) CORRECT:

Acute gastritis manifests with inflammation of the gastric mucosa, often due to direct mucosal injury. Chronic use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) decreases prostaglandin synthesis, reducing mucosal blood flow and compromising the protective mucus barrier. This allows gastric acid to irritate the stomach lining, causing burning epigastric pain that worsens postprandially. Nausea and vomiting are common due to gastric irritation. The patient's history of NSAID use and symptomatology align with the pathophysiology of acute gastritis.

Key learning point: NSAID use can lead to acute gastritis, presenting with epigastric pain that worsens with eating and is relieved by vomiting.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute pancreatitis presents with sudden, severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, often with systemic symptoms like guarding and fever. The patient's gradual onset of postprandial pain and NSAID use suggest a different etiology. Mild tenderness without systemic signs argues against pancreatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholecystitis manifests with acute right upper quadrant pain, possibly radiating to the shoulder, often with fever and a positive Murphy's sign. The patient's epigastric pain post-meals and NSAID use suggest gastric mucosal injury, not gallbladder inflammation. Absence of right upper quadrant tenderness further distances this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He has lost 3.2 kg during this period. His medical history is unremarkable. On examination, he has bilateral pitting pedal edema. Endoscopy reveals prominent rugae in the gastric fundus, and biopsy shows parietal cell atrophy. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic H. pylori infection may cause symptoms of dyspepsia, including abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, as seen in this patient. However, it would not cause edema. On endoscopy, the fundus is typically spared, with predominantly antral lesions showing gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. In addition, histopathologic examination would show H. pylori and chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa with atrophy, gland loss, and metaplastic changes rather than parietal cell atrophy, as seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Neoplasia of the submucosal lymphoid tissue, or gastric lymphoma, can present with abdominal pain and weight loss, although edema would not be expected. Endoscopic findings may also include thickened rugae. However, histopathologic examination would show abnormal lymphoid tissue rather than parietal cell atrophy, as seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's findings are consistent with Ménétrier disease (protein-losing hyperplastic gastropathy), which is a result of the proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells. The pathogenesis involves increased signaling of EGFR, which results in the proliferation of epithelial cells of the mucous cell compartment.

Key learning point: Ménétrier disease is caused by proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells, leading to protein-losing gastropathy, enlarged gastric rugae, and parietal cell atrophy.
Image Description:

CT scan of the abdomen (coronal section, oral and IV contrast)

There is significant hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa that is visible as thick, convoluted rugae projecting into the gastric lumen (green overlay).
A large simple hepatic cyst is also visible in the right lobe of the liver (red overlay).

The appearance of the stomach is typical of hypertrophic gastropathy (Ménétrier disease).

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive somatostatin secretion may be caused by a somatostatinoma. Patients present with abdominal pain and weight loss, in addition to the triad of glucose intolerance, gallstones, and diarrhea/steatorrhea. Edema is not a common feature. If localized to the stomach, the tumor can be seen as a submucosal mass on endoscopy, which is not seen here. In addition, histopathologic examination would show densely granular cells in a rosette pattern, which is a common finding in neuroendocrine tumors.

E) INCORRECT:

Ectopic secretion of gastrin causes Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). Patients with ZES commonly present with dyspeptic symptoms and weight loss, as seen in this patient. However, peptic ulcers, steatorrhea, and upper gastrointestinal bleeding would also be expected. Furthermore, although over 90% of patients with ZES have prominent gastric rugae on endoscopy, a biopsy would show parietal cell hyperplasia rather than atrophy, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dyspeptic symptoms (i.e., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea), weight loss, and possible hypoproteinemia (as evidenced by bilateral pedal edema). In combination with prominent gastric rugae on endoscopy and atrophic parietal cells on histology, these features are diagnostic of Ménétrier disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of burning epigastric pain that worsens with meals, along with bloating and early satiety. She reports taking 600 mg ibuprofen every 6 hours for the past 2 weeks for chronic knee pain from running. She denies fever, weight loss, or dark stools. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness without guarding or rebound. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue ibuprofen and initiate proton pump inhibitors
Obtain urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic symptoms of NSAID-induced gastritis with a clear temporal relationship between symptom onset and ibuprofen use. The most appropriate next step in management is to discontinue the causative agent and initiate proton pump inhibitor therapy. Proton pump inhibitors provide superior acid suppression compared to other agents for treating gastritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate is a cytoprotective agent that can be used adjunctively in peptic ulcer disease, but it is not first-line therapy for gastritis. Primary management should focus on discontinuing the causative agent and providing effective acid suppression.

C) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is not indicated for initial management in patients < 60 years of age with no red flag features such as weight loss, bleeding, or dysphagia. This patient has a clear cause and no alarm symptoms warranting immediate endoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

While acid suppression is required in patients with NSAID-induced gastritis, H2 receptor antagonists are not the most effective option.

E) INCORRECT:

While H. pylori testing is the initial step for most patients with upper gastrointestinal symptoms, this patient has a clear precipitating factor (recent NSAID use), is < 60 years of age, and has no red flag features. The most appropriate next step in management is to address the obvious cause rather than test for H. pylori infection.
